timeline.bodyText: To be safe, I think we should use flip() here in case the limits of the buffers are > the readable bytes. Alternatively, we could use remaining() instead of limit() to calculate the size.
timeline.author: dagnir

replies.bodyText: If the input buffers are not already rewound then I think we'd only want to copy the remaining bytes, so I favor just using .remaining() instead. Do you agree?
replies.author: bmaizels

replies.bodyText: Yeah I think either way works fine.
replies.author: dagnir

timeline.bodyText: The spec requires Publishers to externally synchronize calls to the Subscriber's methods, so we shouldn't need these to be atomics
timeline.author: dagnir

replies.bodyText: Great, I'll tear that out then.
replies.author: bmaizels

timeline.bodyText: Technically we can just ignore any further signals after onComplete/onError, so tracking something like an isDone variable might be easier
timeline.author: dagnir

timeline.bodyText: I'm not sure, but I think this behavior might violate the spec. A Publisher is allowed to signal onComplete without first getting a request() signal, so it's possible that this calls onNext before the downstream subscriber signals any demand which is not allowed
timeline.author: dagnir

replies.bodyText: As discussed we'll change this to not send the envelope at all on an empty stream which is the only scenario we think this will crop up in.

replies.bodyText: As discussed offline, this implementation will never be truly compliant as crudely acts as a man-in-the-middle between an external publisher and subscriber. In this case we control the publisher side, so we're able to hide/mitigate the way we are inserting data where there should be none giving the outward appearance of a compliant publisher to any subscribers. I've marked it internal-only and clearly documented this gotcha/limitation.
replies.author: bmaizels
